texts.shortText: It was recently recognized that several closely-related species were being confused under this one name and thus the previous ‘species’ long known as C. superciliosus has now been split to create six species. These are C. superciliosus itself, which remains valid and indeed is the most common or at least most conspicuous of the ‘daughter’ species, and the new (or resurrected) C. arborescens, C. exasperatus, C. ornatus, C. musaicus and C. spatulatus. It is thus important to note that any biological information (on diet, reproduction, etc) published prior to 2012 refers to the whole group and not just the form now known as C. superciliosus.

Klipfishes of the family Clinidae are smallish, elongate, laterally-compressed, bottom-dwelling fishes with a single dorsal fin stretching head to tail. The pelvic fin is inserted in front of the pectoral fin and consists of just 2–3 elongate rays (and one concealed spine) and the tail is rounded. All species are viviparous and the males have a prominent intromittent organ just behind the anus. The group is particularly common and diverse in intertidal and shallow water systems along the southern and western coasts of South Africa and together these make up the continent’s largest group of endemic fish species.

Clinus superciliosus is one of the larger species in the genus and is the most common clinid at many intertidal and shallow water sites. The head is large and the dorsal fin has 32–38 spines and 8–9 rays, the first three spines being strongly elevated into a conspicuous triangular crest, which is most pronounced in adult males, where it can be 2.5 times the height of the rest of the fin. There is a deep notch after the third spine and the crest spines lack conspicuous cirri but have a single filament at tip. The cirrus above the eye has a short stalk with a flattened end bearing short branches – these being longer and more filamentous in males.

Body colour is extremely variable and can be plain or mottled green, grey, red or brown, but there are usually about 6 vertical half-bars on the dorsal side of the body and often radiating lines from the eyes across the cheeks. Often a dark comma-shaped spot is present on the operculum and a black spot at base of second dorsal spine.

Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: Namibia to Eastern Cape.

A very common species in rock pools and on shallow reefs. Very inquisitive and will often approach snorklers. The body colour changes with habitat, paler individuals often occurring in sandy areas, green ones among seagrasses, red ones among red algae etc. Males grow larger than females.

Diet (assessed before splitting species) consists mostly of crustaceans, polychaetes and mollusks. Smaller prey items, such a copepods, amphipods, isopods and polychaetes declined in importance in larger fish, whereas larger prey such as decapods and mollusks, plus the occasional fish, became more important in large specimens.

Females reach sexual maturity between about 110–120mm and males between 50–60 mm, although males eventually grow much larger than females and there appears to be a dominance hierarchy based on male size (so large males probably  monopolise females). Between 20–144 live young are born per brood at an average length of 20 mm (as assessed before splitting species).
Colour very variable and there are several closely-related species. The best identification features are the large size, robust shape, tall crest on the dorsal fin and lack of cirri on those spines.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 328).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 1 (p. 398).

Holleman, W, Von Der Heyden, S & Zsilavecz, G (2012). Delineating the fishes of the Clinus superciliosus species complex in southern African waters (Blennioidei: Clinidae: Clinini), with the validation of Clinus arborescens Gilchrist & Thompson, 1908 and Clinus ornatus Gilchrist & Thompson, 1908, and with descriptions of two new species. Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society, 166(4), 827-853.

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 765).

Zsilavecz, G (2005). Coastal Fishes of the Cape Peninsula and False Bay. SURG, Cape Town (p. 63).
